docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As noted in ''Scant Drop Seen in Abortions if Parents Are Told'' (front page, March 6), parental notification does not mean that parents tell their children not to have abortions.
docs.abstract: Carol Roye letter says even so-called 'pro-life' parents often try to influence their teenage daughters to have abortions; says policy must be based on public health, not religious beliefs (March 6 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:      As noted in ''Scant Drop Seen in Abortions if Parents Are Told'' (front page, March 6), parental notification does not mean that parents tell their children not to have abortions.

docs.lead_paragraph: Staff members of the new pediatric AIDS clinic here are used to seeing sick children. But rarely had they seen one so ill as the silent, twig-thin youngster led in by his grandmother one hot morning in February. The boy, Tsokotsa Lepheane, age 7, weighed 36 pounds. His hair was thin and patchy, his eyes dull. He stripped to his royal blue underpants slowly, with obvious effort, revealing emaciated limbs and a torso tattooed by a blotchy rash.

headline.main: Slowly, Africa Starts to Care for AIDS Children

docs.snippet: Cheaper drugs are offering hope for children with AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa, but medical staff is scant.

multimedia.credit: Sharon LaFraniere reports that cheaper drugs offer hope for AIDS children, but medical staff is scant.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Sharon LaFraniere reports that cheaper drugs offer hope for AIDS children, but medical staff is scant.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: Africa Sees Hope in AIDS Care

multimedia.caption: Africa Sees Hope in AIDS Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Kevin Sullivan called yesterday for the resignation of the state's victim advocate, James Papillo, over comments he made at a legislative hearing on emergency contraception. Mr. Sullivan, a Democrat, said that Mr. Papillo crossed the line on Monday when he spoke in opposition to a bill requiring all hospitals, including Catholic hospitals, to offer rape victims access to the morning-after pill to prevent an unwanted pregnancy. Mr. Papillo, a deacon in the Roman Catholic Church who was appointed by former Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, said the bill was unnecessary and an assault on religious freedom. Mr. Sullivan accused him of advocating for his personal beliefs and failing to fulfill the mission of his office.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: A Call For Victim Advocate's Resignation

docs.abstract: Connecticut Lt Gov Kevin Sullivan calls for resignation of James Papillo, state's victim advocate, over opposition to emergency contraception for rape victims (S)
